items.headline: Apple’s stock surges to a 2025 high on hot iPhone 17 demand. Can the rally continue?
items.summary_en: Strong early demand for the new iPhone is fueling a rally in Apple’s stock, but some analysts are seeing mixed signals for the pricier models.

items.headline: Oracle is getting two new CEOs. Why that’s good news for the stock.
items.summary_en: With Safra Catz staying involved at Oracle in the role of executive vice chair, investors can expect “a smooth transition” as Clay Magouyrk and Mike Sicilia jointly assume the CEO position.

items.headline: Palantir has ‘main-character energy.’ Here’s how that can help its stock power higher.

items.headline: The small-business hiring engine is sputtering. Why that’s a red flag for the economy.
items.summary_en: Without small businesses and their hiring, already precarious economic growth could be prone to a pullback.

items.headline: Fed chief Powell is talking about the U.S. economy again. And Wall Street is all ears.
items.summary_en: Wall Street has been hanging on every word of Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell as stocks charged to record highs. Investors hope he’ll give more clues Tuesday as to how much the Fed will cut U.S. interest rates.

items.headline: Kenvue says Tylenol is safe, but stock hits record low as Trump makes unproven link to autism
items.summary_en: Shares of Kenvue Inc. sank to a record low Monday, as President Donald Trump warned women to avoid taking Kenvue’s Tylenol, the brand name for acetaminophen, during pregnancy because of a possible connection with autism for the children.

items.headline: Here’s what matters most for Micron’s stock going into earnings
items.summary_en: Improvements in the DRAM and NAND markets led Morgan Stanley to raise its estimates and price target for Micron’s stock, which the analysts say will likely be more driven by clarity on its position with HBM

items.headline: I’m in the U.S. on an H-1B work visa and worried about my job status. What should I do now?
items.summary_en: Legal experts address some common questions as President Trump’s new $100,000 fee on H-1B applications leaves many employees in the U.S. on work visas feeling anxious.

items.headline: ‘I changed my will to deter vultures’: I’m in my 60s and disabled. Do I spend down my assets to qualify for Medicaid?
